Dulle Griet. Here is Hell with representations of Sins and Sinners - to be deciphered with help of the drawings for the Seven Deadly Sins: 1) Toad for Avaritia; 2) The monster [horn?] foreshortened showing anus in front of the naked couple, and this couple underneath the harp tower - for Luxuria; 3) The monster with spoon in anus and bord in hand - for Gula (in the drawing on the right - the combination of the motifs is somewhat difficult); 4) The bird underneath the Gula monster with a plucked peacock (for Superbia) as [...] the from Luxuria; 5) Is there a bear for Ira?; 6) ~ a turkey for Invidia; 7) [Anything?] (snail) for Desidia.[scan]

Bosch-Bruegel. Dulle Griet. Two winged fish-like monsters in the air above the glass bell are from Bosch's Temptation of St. Antony; Styx with boat in Last Judgment: This apparently also in Dulle Griet (above the glass bell to the left) as observed by L. [Leonard] Rosoman, Bruegel's Mad Meg, Lo. [London: Cassell], 1969, p. 27; Rosoman, loc.cit. 'The harp was looked on as a symbol of greed.' [toegevoegde vermelding]: 'F.G. The harp is exactly above Dulle Griet. If this statement about the harp is correct this would confirm my interpretation. Look up Bax: Greed for Rosoman means Gula.

Korte inhoud: [Taal, Duits] Verontschuldigt zich voor het getypte antwoord, immers iedereen klaagt over zijn onleesbaar handschrift. Nodigt Winner bij hem thuis uit. Beoordeel thet programma van de tentoonstelling zeer gunstig, hoopt dat zijn gezondheid hem toelaat de tentoonstelling te bezoeken en dankt voor de uitnodiging het colloquium bij te wonen. Gaat in op de Ripa Grande tekening. Merkt op dat Münz' boek onafgewerkt bleef en dat de Duitse versie beter is dan de Engelse. Vraagt naar watermerktekens en Briquetnummers uit de 'Naer het Leven' reeks opgenomen in Bock-Rosenberg.[scan]

VIII, 21 [...] ; [blad 1, verso] [...] Important for Bruegel's continued occupation with the [onderstreept] Blind, not only in the Proverbs but perhaps also interest in the poor and ailing [onleesbaar] [...]; [blad 2] Addendum Popham B. Was the original a drawing or a painting? The form of the signature (copied) speaks for drawing. Therefore this copy is to be considered among the drawings of 1566. It was probably the design for a painting, in its monumentality cf. Adulteress of 1565.

Ad [Addendum] Bruegel: Suicide of Saul. A drawing by Hans Bol, signed and dated 1568, Basel, Küpferstichkabinett (repr. [Heinrich Gerhard] Franz, [Hans Bol als Landschaftszeichner],  Jb.des Kh.Institutes der Univ. Graz [= Jahrbuch des Kunsthistorischen Institutes der Universität Graz], I, 1965, [pp. 19-67], pl. 46, developed from Bruegel. The group of Saul & his shield bearer (?) large in left foreground. On the right the armies with many figures, but background landscape - Weltlandschaft with high mountains follows Patinir & Mathijs Cock tradition rather than Bruegel. Generally in many early Bol drawings,  i.e. before [onleesbaar], trees like in the 'bear' drawings; Ad [Addendum] Months. Drawing by Hans  Bol, signed and dated 1570 in Louvre, Cabinet des dessins, Inv.N° 20908, repr. Franz, Jb.des Kh.Institutes der Univ. Graz, I, 1965, pl. 57. According to Franz representing 2 months: Sept. & October (Look up Lugt in Louvre Catal.) Bol, Seasons, each time with 3 months, and their zodiac signs. Allegorical figure in center. Hermitage, Franz adest plates 101c-101d, text p. 63 designed for engravings by J. Sadeler, date 1580 (Hollstein, III, p. 54, Nos. 228-231, In Winter (pl. 101d) Pisces, Aquarius, Ram, [onleesbaar] of boar at end under Ram.

Fig. 3 Stormy Harbour  4 x 7cm from Towneley Lectionary, f° 23, Public Libray, New York. Here sky treatment like in Dr. Becker's painting. p. 110 The relationship of this early miniature to Bruegel's work is obvious. It is sufficient to refer to its close connection with the earliest known painting by the master, the Landscape with Sailing Boats and a Burning Town, in a private collection (3) F. GROSSMANN, The Paintings of P. Bruegel the Elder, N° 1 (1955), cat.n° 1, in which the two sailing ships in the centre foreground are almost identical with the two in the left foreground p. 113 of the tiny Bruegel miniature, p. 113 Miniature done in Rome 1553; M. Levi d'Ancona, Illuminati by Clovio Lost & Found, Gaz.B.Arts, 1950, p. 55 very detailed study of Towneley Lectionarium. She dates the Last Judgment miniature hypothetical after 1561; [verso] Webster Smith in MA thesis, Inst. of Fine Arts, New York Univ. (1951) dated the Lectionary between 1550 & 1560.

[= Jahrbuch der kunsthistorischen Sammlungen des allerhöchsten Kaiserhauses, XXXIV, 1918], Taf. XI.

Verlorene Sprichwörter. Tondo für Misanthrop und Tondo für das einselne in sich geschlossene Sprichwort. Der Misanthrop ist Tempera auf Leinwand und ist oft auch in der Wierix Serie kopiert. Kann man nicht daraus schließen, daß andere Sprichwort Tondi (in Wierix Serie und gemalte Kopien) auch auf Leinwand und Tempera waren und daher verloren gegangen sind? Von Bruegel's Leinwand sind nur erhalten: Anbetung Brüssel; Misanthrop; Blinden [?]

BRUEGEL, Way to Calvary. Composition with fantastic steep rock background in centre of the left half... [sic] the whole procession moves across the composition to the right and ending in group under tree (in Bruegel's picture pole with wheel) on right edge, similar in engraving by Cornelis Bos 'The Israelites carrying the Ark across the Jordan', ([Sune] Schéle, Cornelis Bos. [ A Study of the Origins of the Netherland Grotesque, Stockholm: Almqvist & Wiksell, 1965, N° 19, (pls. 6&7) Hollstein 22. Signed and dated 1547, p. 116 According to the dimensions after Giovanni de Molne; According to André de Hevesy, [Quelques tableaux inconnus de Jean Scorel], Oud Holland 1932, [pp. 138-144], p. 138 a painting by Scorel, now lost but described by van Mander!
